summary: heptatitis B virus (DHBV) can naturally infect primary duck hepatocytes. it provides valuable model systems for studying hepadnavirus infection in vitro. the effects of hepadnavirus infection on hepatocytes were investigated. more than 350 million individuals are HBV carriers worldwide. over one-third develop serious liver diseases such as chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis and primary hepatocellular carcinoma. major obstacles in HBV research have been the inability of the virus to infect cells in vitro. DHBV infection of PDHs was determined by indirect immunofluorescence using anti-DHBV preS monoclonal antibody. at 12 h and 24 h after infection, only a few cells showed fluorescence. at 72 h post-infection about 30% expressed viral large surface antigen. DHBV infected PDHs were detected by indirect immunofluorescence staining with mouse anti-DHBV preS mAb. cells were stained with DAPI and visualized by confocal microscopy. the symbol "p.i" represents DHBV post-infection PDHs. differentially expressed protein spots on 2-DE gels were identified by MS/MS analysis. gels of B, D, F and A, C, E represent 2-DE gels obtained from DHBV infected and uninfected PDHs at 24, 72 and 120 h post-infection. protein spot 49 (MW 31 kDa and pI of 5.45) and spot 50 (MW 10 kDa and pI of 5.78) down-regulated in DHBV-infected PDHs were both identified as annexin A2. up-regulated protein spot 26 (MW 65 kDa and pI of 6.61) and spot 27 (MW 66 kDa and pI of 6.4) were matched to lamin A (theoretic gi|37698402 131 34.8/25 8.71/7.80 1 0.5 N 6 Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase(GAPDH) Columba livia gi|6016077 94 35.7/12 8.71/5.79 1 1 0.2 7 Phosphoglycerate kinase 1 Gallus gallus gi|45384486 231 44.7/42 8.31/5.66 2.5 72 52.7/24 6.58/5.45 1 1.2 0.5 Amino acid metabolism 16 unnamed protein product Mus musculus gi|74183518 118 35.8/28 6.84/6.80 1.5 1 1 17 similar to betaine homocysteine methyl transferase Gallus gallus gi|50755288 96 45/44 7.56/6.80 1.5 2 1.5 18 Pterin-4 alpha-carbinolamine dehydratase isoform 1 Canis lupus familiaris gi|73961895 241 20.5/15 4.62/3.80 1 1 A/Ng 29 similar to HSPC162(dynein, light chain) Gallus gallus gi|50758587 86 10.9/11 6.58/5.79 0.5 1 0.33 30 Collapsin response mediator protein-2B Gallus gallus gi|33340025 173 62.2/69 6.05/6.12 N 58kDa glucose regulated protein precursor Gallus gallus gi|45382769 471 72/96 5.12/5.00 N A/N 1 39 Chaperonin containing TCP1, subunit 6A (zeta 1) Gallus gallus gi|57525300 211 57.6/65 6.36/6.60 1 2 1.3 40 58kDa glucose regulated protein precursor Gallus gallus gi|45383890 251 56.1/62 protein score was from MALDI-TOF/TOF identification. the proteins that had a statistically significant score great than 72 (p 0.05) were considered identified. MS spectrum with tryptic peptides of annexin A2 marked in A for peptide QDIAFAYQR. fragments observed in the spectrum were underlined and assigned. roles of selected differentially expressed proteins reported in viral infections were shown in Table 2. alpha-enolase A candidate biomarker for HCV-related hepatocellular carcinoma. required for efficient transcription of Sendai virus genome Takashima et al., 2005. dynein, light chain Regulating Gag and viral RNA egress on endosomal membranes in the cytoplasm to directly impact on viral production. microtubule-dependent dynein activity increased through activation of the p38 MAPK by HBx, perhaps facilitating the process of maturation. 40 endocytosis. required by viral particle up-taking and infection establishment, including HIV, adenovirus, Simian virus 40, and vaccinia virus. annexin A2 Assisting in the assembly of HIV, and supporting HIV-1 infection as a cellular cofactor. enhancing cytomegalovirus binding and membrane fusion and supporting the replication of influenza viruses. anti-beta-actin and anti-duck annexin A2 as primary antibodies were not detected by Western blot analysis. rabbit anti-human or anti-mouse Hsp70 polyclonal antibodies, rabbit anti-human destrin polyclonal antibody and rabbit anti-human lamin A polyclonal antibody. a proteomic analysis compared HepG2 with HepG2.2.15 revealed 19 differentially regulated features in HepaRG cells by 2-DE. hepatoma HepaRG cells are susceptible to HBV, but 1020% of cells can be infected regardless of the amount of virus used. differentially expressed proteins involving in carbohydrate metabolism suggest perturbed energy metabolism in DHBV infections. in lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection, there was a significant increase in transcripts promoting gluconeogenesis for viral mediate synthesis. however, GAPDH and alpha-enolase are decreased in DHBV infected PDHs. in DHBV infected PDHs, the microfilament-associated proteins, beta-actin and cofilin-2 were down-regulated. three microfilament-associated proteins such as transgelin, destrin, and collapsin response mediator protein-2B were up-regulated. actin plays an active role in maturation of the viruses [29,30] s of amino acid metabolism enzymes catalyze interconversion of glutamate, histidine, and proline. glutamate dehydrogenase 1, Urocanate hydratase, delta-1-pyrroline-5-carboxylate dehydrogenase, the orthologs in human referred to protein 16, 19 and 20, 22 in Table 1. a similar mechanism of glutamine metabolism may be at work in DHBV infection. in humanized transgenic mice, inhibition of HBV replication results in suppression of Mn superoxide dismutase expression in hepatocytes [47,48] Annexin A2 belongs to a family of calcium-dependent, phospholipid binding proteins. it is involved in many biological processes, such as the Ca2+ dependent exocytosis, calcium transport and cell proliferation. four-day-old ducklings with no congenital DHBV infection detected by PCR. hepatocytes were isolated with in situ liver perfusion method. vena cava was cut to effuse buffer liquid when the liver was engorged. hepatocytes were seeded onto 100-mm-diameter dish and incubated in L-15 medium containing 5% FBS (Gibco Laboratories), 15 mM HEPES, 100 U penicillin per liter, 100 mg of streptomycin per liter, 1 mg of insulin (Sigma) per liter and 10-5 M hydrocortisone-hemisuccinate (Sigma) at 37°C. the medium was changed every day. monolayers of PDHs grown on glass coverslips were fixed directly by adding 4% polyoxymethylene at room temperature for 20 min, washed twice with PBS and preincubated with 3% bovine serum albumin for 30 min. cells were washed three times with PBS, subsequently incubated with a 1:200 dilution of FITC-conjugated sheep anti-mouse IgG. 2107 cells were lysed in 1 ml lysis buffer (7 M urea, 2 M Thiourea, 2% (w/v) CHAPS, 50 mM dithiothreitol (DTT), 2% (v/v) pH 3-10 nonlinear immobilized pH gradient (IPG) buffer (Amersham Biosciences) then sonicated on ice for 12 cycles, each consisting of 5 s pulse and 10 s pause. IEF was performed as follows: 30 V for 6 h (active rehydration); 60 V for 6 h (active rehydration); 500 V for 2 h, rapid; 1,000 V for 2 h, rapid; 4,000 V for 2 h, linear; linear ramping to 8,000 V for 2 h. then the strips were incubated in equilibration buffer (75 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.8), 6 M urea, 29.3% differentially expressed protein spots with p-values less than 0.05 were considered significant differences. at least 1.5 fold difference in percentage of the volume for each spot was set as a threshold. peptide mixtures from the gel were extracted twice using 0.1% trifluoroacetic/50% ACN at room temperature. myoglobin digested by trypsin was used to calibrate the mass instrument with internal calibration mode. all acquired spectra of samples were processed using 4700 series Explore software. the parent mass peaks with mass range 700-3200 Da and minimum S/N 20 were picked out for tandem TOF/TOF analysis. duck annexin A2 amplified from PDHs was cloned into prokaryotic expression plasmid pET-28a (Novagen) the full-length of duck annexin A2 amplified from PDHs was cloned into prokaryotic expression plasmid pET-28a (Novagen) blots were washed four times with PBS containing 0.1% Tween-20. the bands were developed with ECL detection reagent (Pierce) the same amount protein of each sample was applied to a parallel SDS-PAGE gel and stained with Coomassie brilliant blue. 4 106 hepatocytes were seeded onto 100-mm-diameter dish and incubated in L-15 medium containing 5% FBS (Gibco Laboratories), 15 mM HEPES, 100 U penicillin per liter, 100 mg of streptomycin per liter and 10-5 M hydrocortisone-hemisuccinate (Sigma) at 37°C. the medium was changed every day. cells were washed twice with PBS and preincubated with 3% bovine serum albumin. cell nucleus were stained with 1 g/ml 4',6'-diamidino-2-phenylindole (DAPI, Sigma) and mounted in 50% glycerol in PBS. dithiothreitol (DTT), 2% (v/v) pH 3-10 nonlinear immobilized pH gradient (PPA) buffer (Amersham Biosciences) containing 1% protease inhibitor cocktail (Roche) and 1 mM PMSF (Sigma) then sonicated on ice for 12 cycles. after centrifugation at 20,000 g at 4°C for 1 h, the supernatants of lysates were divided into the IPG strips were incubated in equilibration buffer (75 mM Tris-HCl (pH 8.8), 6 M urea, 29.3% (v/v) glycerol, 2% (w/v) SDS and 0.002% (w/v) bromophenol blue) for 15 min with gentle agitation. the gels were stained by a modified silver staining method compatible with MS analysis. in-gel tryptic digestion The differentially expressed protein spots were manually excised from the sliver-stained gels. the gel pieces were destained with a solution of 15 mM potassium ferricyanide and 50 mM sodium thiosulfate (1:1) at room temperature for 10 min. the samples were swollen in a digestion buffer containing 25 mM NH4HCO3 and 12.5 ng/l trypsin (Promega Combined MS and MS/MS spectra were submitted to MASCOT by GPS Explorer software. the individual MS/MS spectrum with statistically significant (confidence interval >95%) and best ion score (based on MS/MS spectra) was singled out. mice were immunized by the purified recombinant duck annexin A2 with Freund's complete adjuvant (Sigma) the serum was collected 2 weeks following the final injection and the levels of anti-duck-annexin A2 antibody titers from immunized mice were determined by Western blot analysis. the same amount protein of each sample was applied to a parallel SDS-PAGE gel and stained with Coomassie brilliant blue. YZ and LY were responsible for PDHs culture, virus infection and sample preparation. DHBV DNA in PDHs was detected by Southern blot hybridization with an alpha-32P-dCTP labeled DHBV-specific probe. the numbers of differentially expressed protein spots detected by 2-DE at 24, 72, 120 h post-DHBV infection were listed. the expression ratio between DHBV infected and uninfected PDHs of unidentified spots underlined in Figure 2 were listed. 2008ZX10004-014, 2008ZX10002-002 and 2008ZX10002-011.
